citation.abstract: In this review we look at this biological overlaps of neurodegenerative and psychiatric conditions, as exemplified by major depressive disorder (MDD). Recent work has highlighted how immune-inflammatory processes and their interactions with oxidative and nitrosative stress (O&NS), couple to drive changes in neuroregulatory tryptophan catabolite (TRYCAT), with consequences for serotonin availability for the melatonergic pathways. Such work significantly questions the validity and utility of non-biologically based current classification systems for psychiatric and neurodegenerative conditions. The biological underpinnings of Alzheimer&#039;s disease, Parkinson&#039;s disease and multiple sclerosis are reviewed and overlapped with the biological changes associated with MDD. This is done in the context of integrating alterations in immune-inflammation, O&NS, TRYCATs and the melatonergic pathways. Such a model better integrates wider aspects of current research, including the role of the gut-brain axis, which involves alterations in gut microbiota and increases in the levels of gut permeability in driving changes centrally.
